bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 8, 1923

div1.p: Carter returns comments on Vaughn's article to Russell, and discusses his comments.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 8, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Vaughn's article
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 8, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I am returning Dr. Vaughn's article with Memorandum of criti-
cisms referring to my pencilled numbers on the margin thereof. Had
Dr. Vaughn been present I would have called his attention to about as
many more.

Pretty much everything that should be in an article of this kind
is in this paper and but little that should not be, but I think he
could have arranged and grouped his data to better advantage.

I think if Dr. Vaughn would give us a paper upon his fulminant
cases of yellow fever with full clinical history it would be valuable.
It seems to me he does not consider black water a differential be-
tween them and the so-called “black water fever.”

I have never seen a case of black water in yellow fever and my
experience is the same, I think, as that of all the recognized au-
thorities on it, except the older practitioners--in Africa especial-
ly--when no distinction was made, except in severity, between yellow
fever and malaria. The cases that I have seen which were absolutely
fulminant--one dying within six or eight hours--died of pure tox-
emia, the facies being simply darkly congested and none of them vom-
iting blood though there was blood in the stomachs of all of them.

I would really like to see for myself a series of these fulminant
cases of which Vaughn speaks and since I cannot, would be extremely
extremely
glad to have a good clinical history with autopsy reports.
